titlePart.supplied: What Municipalities in the West Have Been doing to Promote Birth Control

sourceDesc.bibl: "Benefits of Birth Control", Times of India, Nov. 30, 1935, p. 22.

headNote.p: A summary and quotes of Sanger's Nov. 29, 1935 speech to the Bombay Municipal Corporation came from "Benefits of Birth Control," Times of India, Nov. 30, 1935, p. 22.

docBody.head: Benefits of Birth Control
Mrs. Sanger's Plea to Bombay Municipality
docBody.p: “Close on 50,000 of our women have benefit[t]ed by the practice of birth control, and if today they are living, it is because of the useful information they got at our clinics.” declared Mrs. Margaret Sanger, Chairman of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control, New York, in reply to a question put to her at a meeting held in the Bombay Municipal Corporation hall, on Friday evening. The theme of her lecture was “What Municipalities in the West have been doing to promote birth control.” She was accompanied by Mrs. Edith How-Martyn, Honorary Director, Birth Control International Information Centre, London, who also addressed the meeting. There was a large gathering.

p.q: The mayor, Mr. K. F. Nariman, who presided, accorded the visitors a cordial welcome on behalf of the citizens of Bombay and appealed to them to confine their humanitarian mission not merely to large cities in India, but to spread it in the villages, where relief was urgently needed.

When they were able to control their appetite and other things, said Mrs. Sanger, they could as well control the greatest of all problems, that of population. In America and Holland the knowledge of birth control was widely spread, and consequently there were fewer deaths among infants and less maternal mortality. Greater attention was being paid to social welfare and to allied problems. In Holland she found that the population had increased on sound lines. Birth control was not at all harmful; it was on the other hand, beneficial, and helped to decrease maternal mortality.

q.p: Mrs. Sanger asked the Bombay Municipality to take the lead in the movement by starting birth control clinics, as other western municipalities had already done. If the knowledge of birth control were systematically and scientifically spread among the masses, it would do them enormous good, and within a hundred years the people would appreciate the efforts of the municipality and raise a statue to the Mayor for having successfully launched the movement. (Laughter.)

Mrs. How-Martyn explained how attention was being paid to the movement in England, pointing out that large sums of money were being spent on social service. Hundreds of women took advantage of the birth control clinics started in various parts of the country.
The visitors answered several questions asked by members of the audience and cleared their doubts on the subject.
